messageBody:
Object Technology: A Manager's Guide, by David Taylor is the best
introduction to objects I know of and it is under 200pgs. Of course as
someone already mentioned the very best way to learn how to program (not
just how to write code in a particular language). Is to be mentored by
someone who is already an expert.


-----Original Message-----
From: mamago@... [mailto:mamago@...]
Sent: Friday, December 13, 2002 10:53 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] OT: OO Newcomer


OFF TOPIC
Disclaimer: see below

Bringing a newbie into OO
=========================

I would like to ask the people on this list for recommendations of the
best literature to bring an OO newbie up to speed.

The programming language in question is Java, which means that there is
a splendid wealth of online material for someone to learn the language.
The important thing, however, is to instill the notion of OO purity,
which is harder, perhaps, than just teaching the language.

For example: the GoF patterns book is a must, but I think it is not a
text that you can give to someone until they have a grounding in OO
techniques.

Your thoughts?

Manuel Amago.

-----------------------------------------------
DISCLAIMER
I know this group is not for this type of question, which is why I
explicitly labelled this thread as OT (Off Topic). I hope you will
forgive my impertinence. ;) But, I greatly value the opinions of the
people on this list, and I trust your opinion on this particular issue.
